title: 112_hr6494
content: The Act is titled the "Stewart Lee Udall Congressional Gold Medal Act" and includes findings. Stewart Lee Udall was born in 1920 in Saint Johns, Arizona, to former Arizona Supreme Court Justice Levi Stewart Udall and Louise Lee Udall. He served in the United States Army Air Corps during World War II, flying over 50 missions in Western Europe. After the war, he returned to the University of Arizona, where he earned a bachelor's and law degree, eventually establishing his own law firm. Stewart L. Udall served in the United States Army Air Corps during World War II and later established a law firm with his brother. He was elected to various positions, including United States Representative and Secretary of the Interior under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, where he was praised for his environmental and conservation efforts. During his cabinet career, Stewart L. Udall played a key role in passing significant environmental legislation, such as the Wilderness Act of 1964, Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965, and Endangered Species Preservation Act of 1966. He also coauthored the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, which created social programs like Head Start and the Job Corps. Stewart L. Udall, as Secretary of the Interior, expanded the National Park Service by acquiring 3.85 million acres of new holdings, including 4 national parks and various other conservation areas. He also established the Bureau of Outdoor Recreation and initiated Project EROS, leading to advancements in satellite imagery technology. Project EROS, the longest running satellite imagery acquisition program, was initiated by Stewart L. Udall during his tenure as Secretary of the Interior. Udall also championed the arts, leading to the creation of various cultural institutions and fighting against segregation. Stewart L. Udall threatened to deny the all-white Washington Redskins access to the new DC stadium as the Federal landlord. After leaving government service, he advocated for victims of radiation exposure, helped pass the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act, and was a prolific writer, receiving honors such as the Ansel Adams Award. Stewart L. Udall received several prestigious awards for his lifelong dedication to environmental protection and advocacy for victims of nuclear weapons testing. Until his passing in 2010, he continued his public service through various roles such as author, historian, scholar, lecturer, environmental activist, lawyer, and outdoor enthusiast. Stewart Lee Udall will be honored with a posthumous Congressional Gold Medal for his contributions to the nation. The medal will be presented by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The design and striking of the medal will be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary has the authority to create and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale will be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the costs of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will go back into the Fund.
